comments.content:
Me too. Do you have any more letters? The [Serif Font ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20100204201817/http:/www.bowfinprintworks.com/SerifGuide/intro.php) should help, but all this gives me is the 'a' and an ambiguous 'y' to use in the key letter search. I tried WhatTheFont with this image, and got bogus choices.

- Mike Yanega
Bingo. One of those pesky windows fonts

Good one, Ben! I was thinking [FF Eureka](http://web.archive.org/web/20100204201817/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontlist/super_families/ff_eureka/?&sample_text=Family&sample_size=144).  
Sylfaen [had stumped us before](http://web.archive.org/web/20100204201817/http:/typophile.com/node/29571).
Something about the pointy flat arches on the m does it for me. Gosh, looks like everybody was stumped on that other thread!

I see I need to add a couple of other ways to describe that 'y'. I missed it because I kept picking the wrong y tail shape. I don't know what I was thinking when I coded it the first time. ;-(

- Mike Yanega

That sample isn't very good - it's not really so blobby.  
I would call it a "sheared flare" or an "adnate wedge".

hhp

The descriptions are not made in words for the Serif Guide. You make a choice of which y seems closest to the one in the font. It was coded to choose the 5th y, but I expanded it to allow the 2nd and 4th as well.

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100204201817im_/http:/typophile.com/files/y-shape_SerifGuide_4161.gif)
